title: 113_s2399
content: The "Native Voting Rights Act of 2014" is also known as the Act. It addresses tribal identification and actions for disparities in polling place availability. The Voting Rights Act is amended to allow tribal identification documents to be used for voting purposes. The Attorney General can take action if there is a disparity in voting opportunities for members of Indian tribes. Measures can be taken to reduce this disparity by increasing polling place availability. The Attorney General can address disparities in voting opportunities for members of Indian tribes by increasing polling place availability. District courts have jurisdiction over such actions, which must be heard by a panel of three judges and can be appealed to the Supreme Court. There is a presumption that such disparities may deny the right to vote based on race or color. The Attorney General can expedite actions addressing disparities in voting opportunities for members of Indian tribes. An aggrieved person may bring an action to address denial of voting rights based on race or color. PROTECTIONS RELATING TO POLLING PLACES ON INDIAN RESERVATIONS. Protections Relating to Indian Reservations under Section 4 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 include requirements for approval before eliminating or moving polling places on Indian reservations. Protections under Section 4 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 include restrictions on moving or consolidating polling places on Indian reservations, eliminating in-person voting, removing early voting locations, and decreasing voting hours on Indian reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 prohibits changes to voting procedures on Indian reservations, including altering in-person or early voting dates. Amendments to Section 5(a) expand protections to include any activities described in subsection (g) of section 4. SEC. 4 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations if a written complaint is received regarding potential voter rights violations. SEC. 5 addresses the termination of election observers. SEC. 5 amends Section 13(a) of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 to terminate election observers appointed under subsection (b) of section 8 after the next general election for President. SEC. 6 amends the Voting Rights Act of 1965 to define terms related to Indian tribes and tribal organizations. SEC. 7 updates bilingual election requirements under the Act. The Attorney General must release reports of Federal election observers within 6 months. The Attorney General should consult with tribal organizations annually on voting issues for Indian tribes.
